user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_auth_rq_header_:
```c
static bool
find_auth_rq_header_ (const struct MHD_Connection *c, enum MHD_AuthType type,
                      struct _MHD_str_w_len *auth_value)
{
  const struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *h;
  const char *token;
  size_t token_len;

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED <= c->state);
  if (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > c->state)
    return false;

#ifdef DAUTH_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_AUTHTYPE_DIGEST == type)
  {
    token = _MHD_AUTH_DIGEST_BASE;
    token_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (_MHD_AUTH_DIGEST_BASE);
  }
  else /* combined with the next line */
#endif /* DAUTH_SUPPORT */
#ifdef BAUTH_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_AUTHTYPE_BASIC == type)
  {
    token = _MHD_AUTH_BASIC_BASE;
    token_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (_MHD_AUTH_BASIC_BASE);
  }
  else /* combined with the next line */
#endif /* BAUTH_SUPPORT */
  {
    mhd_assert (0);
    return false;
  }

  for (h = c->rq.headers_received; NULL != h; h = h->next)
  {
    if (MHD_HEADER_KIND != h->kind)
      continue;
    if (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION) != h->header_size)
      continue;
    if (token_len > h->value_size)
      continue;
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION,
                                         h->header,
                                         MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                           MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION)))
      continue;
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (h->value, token, token_len))
      continue;
    /* Match only if token string is full header value or token is
     * followed by space or tab
     * Note: RFC 9110 (and RFC 7234) allows only space character, but
     * tab is supported here as well for additional flexibility and uniformity
     * as tabs are supported as separators between parameters.
     */
    if ((token_len == h->value_size) ||
        (' ' == h->value[token_len]) || ('\t'  == h->value[token_len]))
    {
      if (token_len != h->value_size)
      { /* Skip whitespace */
        auth_value->str = h->value + token_len + 1;
        auth_value->len = h->value_size - (token_len + 1);
      }
      else
      { /* No whitespace to skip */
        auth_value->str = h->value + token_len;
        auth_value->len = h->value_size - token_len;
      }
      return true; /* Found a match */
    }
  }
  return false; /* No matching header has been found */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function parameters are: const struct MHD_Connection *c, enum MHD_AuthType type, and struct _MHD_str_w_len *auth_value. Rule 17.8 forbids modifying a parameter itself (reassigning the parameter variable), but explicitly allows modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter. In the code: - There are no assignments to c or type (neither pointer nor enum parameter is reassigned). - The only mutations are to members of *auth_value (auth_value->str and auth_value->len), which modify the object pointed to by the pointer parameter — this is permitted by the rule. - No parameter pointer variables are reassigned (no auth_value = ..., no c = ..., no type = ...). - All other assignments are to local variables (token, token_len, h). Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and no code fragments require further investigation for this rule.
